customer_addr:
9008 Front Beach Road
Panama City Beach, FL 32407

citations.narrative:
*** At the time of the inspection, there were guests in the budgie aviary with feed sticks feeding and interacting with the
budgies. There was no attendant present inside the aviary who was knowledgeable and readily identifiable that could
instruct guests in how to safety interact with the budgies or give instruction in how to properly feed the budgies for the
safety of the birds.
*** At the time of the inspection there were guests interacting with the rabbits through touch and there was no attendant
present near the rabbits who was readily identifiable and knowledgeable about the species.
The facility stated that the staff member who was selling coffee at a cart in front of the vet hospital was the “readily
identifiable” attendant stationed for the budgie aviary and the rabbit encounter area. The staff member selling coffee was
approximately 33 paces from the rabbit enclosure and 13 paces from the double door entry to the aviary. From the
location of the coffee cart, the inspectors did not have a good line of sight into the aviary to be able to ascertain how
guests were handling and feeding the birds. Additionally, the inspectors did not have a clear line of sight to the guest
interactions with the rabbits while standing at the coffee cart. The only thing clearly visualized was the backsides of the
guests as they bent over to interact with the rabbits. For the overall health and welfare of the birds, a responsible,
knowledgeable and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods of public
contact.

At the time of the inspection, the facility had placed concrete blocks which had been intentionally broken up into pieces
around the fence line in the hyena/lion holding yard to mitigate digging by the hyenas. Some of the concrete has sharp
points and the presence of broken concrete does not keep the area in good repair nor protect the animals from potential
injury when they are digging at the concrete and sand underneath. These broken pieces of concrete should be removed
and another method of digging mitigation addressed to keep the area safe for the animals.
Correct by: Jan 15, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
ANDREA D AMBROSIO, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
2.131(d)(2)  Repeat
   
Handling of animals. 
*** At the time of the inspection, there were guests in the budgie aviary with feed sticks feeding and interacting with the 
budgies. There was no attendant present inside the aviary who was knowledgeable and readily identifiable that could 
instruct guests in how to safety interact with the budgies or give instruction in how to properly feed the budgies for the 
safety of the birds.  
 
*** At the time of the inspection there were guests interacting with the rabbits through touch and there was no attendant 
present near the rabbits who was readily identifiable and knowledgeable about the species.  
 
The facility stated that the staff member who was selling coffee at a cart in front of the vet hospital was the “readily 
identifiable” attendant stationed for the budgie aviary and the rabbit encounter area. The staff member selling coffee was 
approximately 33 paces from the rabbit enclosure and 13 paces from the double door entry to the aviary. From the 
location of the coffee cart, the inspectors did not have a good line of sight into the aviary to be able to ascertain how 
guests were handling and feeding the birds. Additionally, the inspectors did not have a clear line of sight to the guest 
interactions with the rabbits while standing at the coffee cart. The only thing clearly visualized was the backsides of the 
guests as they bent over to interact with the rabbits. For the overall health and welfare of the birds, a responsible, 
knowledgeable and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods of public 
contact. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
At the time of the inspection, the facility had placed concrete blocks which had been intentionally broken up into pieces 
around the fence line in the hyena/lion holding yard to mitigate digging by the hyenas. Some of the concrete has sharp 
points and the presence of broken concrete does not keep the area in good repair nor protect the animals from potential 
injury when they are digging at the concrete and sand underneath. These broken pieces of concrete should be removed 
and another method of digging mitigation addressed to keep the area safe for the animals.  
Correct by: Jan 15, 2025

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
ANDREA D AMBROSIO, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
